The determination as to whether the President committed wrongdoing lies with Congress. And the #MuellerReport lays out a very strong case on Obstruction of Justice. 3/3

But Mueller also said, "If we had confidence that the president clearly had not committed a crime, we would have said so. We did not however make a determination as to whether the president did commit a crime." 2/3

Mueller should testify before Congress and the evidence that Mueller relied upon should also be made available to Congress. As Mueller said, given the Justice Department's policies, it was not his job to make a determination on whether the President committed a crime. 1/3

I met with MP Betty Nambooze of Uganda and others concerned with human rights. We discussed human rights abuses in Uganda. I am proud to support Ugandans’ right to free participation in elections, and to end the practice of torture in all its forms. pic.twitter.com/VcDBc36Da6

Today we took a major step towards LGBTQ equality with the passage of the #EqualityAct in the House (H.R. 5). I was proud to have co-sponsored this bill which prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in housing, employment, and credit.

This bill would prohibit any child welfare agency from discriminating against any potential foster or adoptive family on the basis of sexual orientation, gender identity, religion or marital status. 2/2 pic.twitter.com/1eABnxDRAg

I was pleased to meet with the @family_equality and my friend and Valley Resident @Karamo from @Queereye. Although he did not give me any style tips, we did discuss my support for the Every Child Deserves A Family Act. 1/2 pic.twitter.com/hsn9vpENlP
